playing_against_defenders.probleme: Struggling to play effectively against defensive choppers and blockers.
causes_communes: Serving long and letting the defender settle into position.
Allowing defender to stay back without in–out movement pressure.

debutant: Vary serves; include short serves to bring defender close to the table before your next attack.
Aim strong attacks at the defender’s middle/crossover to jam them.
Use short pushes or drop shots that land close to the net to bring the defender in.
Watch the ball closely to read spin; if unsure, play safely onto the table.
Adopt a patient mindset; reduce easy mistakes and wait for the next ball.
intermediaire: Decide which wing (FH/BH) the defender retrieves fast balls better; direct faster balls to the weaker side.
Identify which wing copes worse with slower, spinny topspin; vary speed accordingly.
Alternate short balls (to bring them in) with a quick attack to the body or wide angle.
When under pressure, push or play safely to the weaker attacking side.
avance: Exploit in–out patterns: short ball to draw in, immediate fast attack to the crossover.
Manipulate spin and speed to limit the defender’s ability to add deceptive variation.
Chain placements: wide FH ↔ body ↔ wide BH with tempo changes to break rhythm.

exercices_complementaires.description: Serve or drop short to draw the defender in; next ball attack fast to the crossover; reset and repeat.

erreurs_a_eviter: Hitting slow balls to the crossover (gives time to adjust).
Overhitting early instead of staying patient when they lack a strong attack.

table_tennis_robots.probleme: How and when to use table tennis robots for training.
causes_communes: No training partner available; limited time to travel to a club.
Overreliance on robots leading to lack of visual cue reading.
Neglecting ball-flight feedback because attention switches to next fed ball.

debutant: Use a robot when you cannot find a partner; prioritize consistent feed to build efficient, fluent strokes.
Focus on start/finish positions and tension levels in arm, wrist, fingers, and toes.
Watch some balls after contact to get feedback on shot quality instead of immediately tracking the next feed.
intermediaire: Program placement to multiple positions (up to 6–8 if available) to practice movement and patterns.
Vary spin and speed across balls if the machine allows; include no-spin and different spins within a drill.
Balance robot training with partner sessions to practice reading cues like backswing and body position.
avance: Save and revisit a library of drills; run high-tempo feeds (up to around 100 balls/min if available) to stress movement and recovery.
Design drills that force you to watch your outgoing ball for feedback, then reacquire the next feed late to simulate rally vision.

exercices_complementaires.description: Robot feeds same speed/spin to one location; focus on relaxed grip, clean start/finish; occasionally pause to observe ball flight.
Program 6–8 positions per sequence; alternate FH/BH and include a body ball; add spin and speed variation if possible.

erreurs_a_eviter: Treating robot feeds as realistic substitutes for opponent cues.
Ignoring feedback from your own shot because you immediately watch the robot for the next ball.

meta.article_title: Can You Pass The Serving Test?

can_you_pass_the_serving_test.probleme: Serving to ‘bad areas’ reduces serve effectiveness.
can_you_pass_the_serving_test.diagnostic: Many players serve to mid-depth zones; average opponents may not punish this, hiding the flaw.
causes_communes: Compromising spin to keep the ball short instead of using a brushing contact.
Lack of intent to serve either very short (double-bounce) or very long and fast to corners.

debutant: Target good areas: either short double-bounce or very long and fast to corners.
Use a brushing contact to maintain heavy spin while keeping the ball short.
intermediaire: Perform the 10-ball short-serve test regularly; keep spin high while controlling length.
Serve short about 80% of the time to force receiver movement and protect against full swings.
avance: At high control (scores 9–10), work on subtle variations of spin and speed while maintaining short length.

exercices_complementaires.description: With your favorite serve, deliver 10 balls that would bounce twice if untouched; keep a brushing contact to preserve spin; record score.

metriques_progression: Number out of 10 serves that bounce twice short (target scale: 0–10 with qualitative comments provided).
Proportion of short serves in play (~80% suggested).
erreurs_a_eviter: Serving mid-depth to the bad zone.
Reducing spin to make the ball short.

meta.article_title: The First Step to a Great Pendulum Serve

the_first_step_to_a_great_pendulum_serve.probleme: Limited wrist mobility with standard shakehand grip reduces spin and deception on pendulum serves.
the_first_step_to_a_great_pendulum_serve.diagnostic: Standard shakehand grip restricts wrist range, limiting spin generation and disguise.
causes_communes: Gripping with all fingers on the handle during serve.
Insufficient wrist freedom leading to slower swing speed at contact.

debutant: Modify grip: remove the 3 lower fingers from the handle and make a fist behind it; grip mainly with thumb and index finger.
Slide index finger further onto the backhand rubber to free the wrist.
intermediaire: Compare normal vs. modified grip by attempting pendulum serves; observe increased wrist range with the modified grip.
Emphasize wrist movement to increase swing speed and spin.
avance: Use the modified grip to vary spin amounts and disguise serves once basic control is established.

exercices_complementaires.description: Perform 10 pendulum serves with standard grip, then 10 with modified thumb–index grip; note wrist range and spin difference.

metriques_progression: Subjective increase in wrist range of motion and observed spin after switching grips.
erreurs_a_eviter: Keeping all fingers on the handle during pendulum serve, which restricts the wrist.
